questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician for preconceptional advice. She has been married for 2 years and would like to conceive within the next year. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and last 4 days with normal flow. She does not smoke or drink alcohol and follows a balanced diet. She takes no medications. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 55 kg (121 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Physical examination, including pelvic examination, shows no abnormalities. She has adequate knowledge of the fertile days of her menstrual cycle. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Supplementation of folic acid (0.4–0.8 mg/day) is recommended in all patients trying to conceive. Ideally, women should begin taking a supplement ≥ 4 weeks before trying to conceive and continue with this dose until 12 weeks of gestational age to meet the increased demand of folate due to fetal neural tube development and maternal and fetal erythropoiesis. If there is a folate deficiency, neural tube defects (e.g., anencephaly, meningomyelocele) and megaloblastic anemia may occur.

B) INCORRECT:

In the absence of severe deficiency, excessive intake of vitamin A is contraindicated in pregnant women and women who may become pregnant within the next 60 days. Vitamin A doses greater than the recommended dietary allowance in pregnancy (> 770 mcg/day or > 2560 units/day) may cause craniofacial malformations or central nervous system, heart, or thymus abnormalities in the fetus.

C) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 supplementation is recommended for pregnant women who adhere to a vegan diet since vitamin B12 is mainly found in red meat, fish, and dairy products. Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to maternal and fetal megaloblastic anemia. This patient does not follow a vegan diet and is not yet pregnant, making vitamin B12 supplementation unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Iron supplementation of 30–60 mg/d is recommended during pregnancy to meet the increased iron demand due to maternal and fetal erythropoiesis. Iron deficiency in pregnancy may cause maternal and fetal anemia and increases the risk of placental insufficiency. Since this patient shows no symptoms of iron deficiency anemia, such as fatigue or pallor, iron supplementation is not necessary prior to conception.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients who are underweight can experience difficulty conceiving. If the patient were underweight and having problems becoming pregnant, gaining weight might be advised. Gaining extra weight prior to conception is not necessary in this case, as the woman has a normal BMI. Over the course of pregnancy, she should gain 25–35 lbs (about 11–16 kg).
questions.hint: Which of the following is most likely to decrease the risk of neural tube defects such as spina bifida and anencephaly in the fetus?

questions.text:
A 28-year-old gravida 1, para 1 woman with polycystic ovary syndrome and recently diagnosed type 2 diabetes is planning a second pregnancy. Her first child was conceived while she was taking metformin 5 years ago. Since then, she has discontinued metformin on her own initiative. She stopped her oral contraceptives about 18 months ago in hopes of becoming pregnant again. She has had oligomenorrhea and has been engaging in regular intercourse without contraception.
Her heart rate is 82 beats per minute, her blood pressure is 122/78 mm Hg, and her BMI is 35.
Her glycated hemoglobin level is 8.0% (target, <7.0%), her thyroid-stimulating hormone level is 1.2 μU/mL (reference range, 0.5–4.7), and her creatinine concentration is 0.85 mg/dL (0.6–1.1). Her fasting blood glucose levels range from the 170s to the 180s (reference range, 70–100 mg/dL).
A urine pregnancy test is negative.
In addition to exercise and nutritional management, what is the most appropriate next step in care for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sulfonylureas such as glyburide may help control this patient’s hyperglycemia but would not help address her anovulatory cycles and are therefore not the best initial treatment for her. Guidelines on gestational diabetes from the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists suggest that glyburide is also appropriate for achieving glycemic control during pregnancy, but the ADA expressed concerns about the concentration of glyburide levels in cord blood.

Letrozole is the recommended first-line treatment for infertility in patients with PCOS. However, this patient’s diabetes is uncontrolled; therefore, ovulation induction is premature. Metformin will address the patient’s uncontrolled diabetes and may help induce ovulatory cycles. If metformin controls the diabetes but fails to induce ovulation, letrozole may be considered.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has anovulatory infertility secondary to polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). She also has obesity and uncontrolled type 2 diabetes, which, if she becomes pregnant, will increase her risk for gestational hypertension, preeclampsia, congenital anomalies, fetal macrosomia, spontaneous abortion, and other maternal and fetal morbidities. Strict glycemic control before pregnancy is important for this patient and can be met by targeting fasting glucose levels ≤95 mg/dL and glycated hemoglobin concentrations ≤6.0% to 7.0%. Nutritional counseling and a low-carbohydrate diet should be part of her management plan, but she also needs medication to help with her hyperglycemia. In addition, she should be counseled to use contraception to delay her pregnancy plans until her diabetes is better controlled.

Metformin is the best initial medication in a patient with uncontrolled diabetes and infertility from PCOS, as it addresses both the hyperglycemia and the anovulatory cycles. Treatment with metformin may help to restore ovulation, improve insulin sensitivity, and reduce serum androgen levels, without any risk of hypoglycemia.

Other diabetes medications — including insulin — may help control this patient’s hyperglycemia but would not help address her anovulatory cycles and are therefore not the best initial treatment for her.

Given that this patient is planning to become pregnant, one must also consider the safety of diabetes medications in pregnancy. Most forms of insulin have a well-established safety profile in pregnancy and are recommended by the American Diabetes Association (ADA) and the Endocrine Society as first-line therapy for diabetes in pregnancy. Guidelines on gestational diabetes from the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists suggest that glyburide and metformin are also appropriate for achieving glycemic control during pregnancy, but the ADA expressed concerns about the concentration of metformin on the fetal side of the placenta and glyburide levels in cord blood. When a woman with PCOS wishes to become pregnant, standard practice is to start metformin and then discuss the pros and cons of switching to insulin once the woman becomes pregnant.

Key learning point: The optimal diabetes medication for a woman with uncontrolled type 2 diabetes who has anovulatory infertility from polycystic ovary syndrome and is planning a pregnancy is metformin; in addition, contraception should be recommended until better glycemic control is achieved.

C) INCORRECT:

Clomiphene is no longer considered first-line medical treatment for infertility in PCOS based on evidence demonstrating the superiority of letrozole; it may be considered on a case-by-case basis but only after metformin alone has been attempted.

D) INCORRECT:

Letrozole is the recommended first-line treatment for infertility in patients with PCOS. However, this patient’s diabetes is uncontrolled; therefore, ovulation induction is premature. Metformin will address the patient’s uncontrolled diabetes and may help induce ovulatory cycles. If metformin controls the diabetes but fails to induce ovulation, letrozole may be considered.

E) INCORRECT:

Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitors such as sitagliptin may help control this patient’s hyperglycemia but would not help address her anovulatory cycles and are therefore not the best initial treatment for her.

Given that this patient is planning to become pregnant, one must also consider the safety of diabetes medications in pregnancy. Sitagliptin has not been studied in pregnancy.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman and her husband present for preconception counseling. The couple’s families are originally from eastern Europe and are of Ashkenazi Jewish descent. The woman and her husband are healthy and have no known medical problems.
The woman’s niece has a genetic condition affecting her nervous system and is developmentally delayed.
The couple would like to know their risk of having an infant with a serious, genetically inherited disease.
For which one of the following conditions should this couple be screened?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ataxia-telangiectasia is an autosomal recessive disorder that can lead to progressive ataxia and other neurologic abnormalities. This disorder is diagnosed with genetic testing. Prenatal genetic screening for this neurologic condition is usually reserved for people with a personal or family history of ataxia or other neurologic disorders. Ataxia telangiectasia is not limited to certain ethnic groups.

B) CORRECT:

Ashkenazi Jews, descendants of eastern European Jews, have a higher prevalence of autosomal recessive disease conditions than other individuals do. The American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology recommends that Ashkenazi Jews undergo preconception carrier-status screening for Tay-Sachs disease (TSD), cystic fibrosis, Canavan disease, and familial dysautonomia. These disorders are most often severe, untreatable, and associated with reduced life expectancy. Notably, all Ashkenazi Jews should undergo preconception carrier-status screening, not just those with a family history of one of these diseases.

The American College of Medical Genetics recommends that Ashkenazi Jews also undergo additional carrier screening for Fanconi anemia (group C), Niemann-Pick disease (type A), Bloom syndrome, mucolipidosis type IV, and Gaucher disease. The screening tests for these disorders have high positive predictive value in the Ashkenazi Jewish population.

Tay-Sachs disease is a progressive disorder affecting the central nervous system, causing weakness, loss of motor skills, and death within the first few years of life. TSD is caused by a deficiency in the hexosaminidase A enzyme.

Key learning point: The American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology recommends preconception genetic screening for carrier status of Tay-Sachs disease, cystic fibrosis, Canavan disease, and familial dysautonomia in couples whose ethnic background is Ashkenazi Jewish.

C) INCORRECT:

Friedreich ataxia is an autosomal recessive disorder that can lead to progressive ataxia and other neurologic abnormalities. This disorder is diagnosed with genetic testing. Prenatal genetic screening for this neurologic condition is usually reserved for people with a personal or family history of ataxia or other neurologic disorders. Friedreich ataxia may be more prevalent in some ethnic groups, such as those with Cajun ancestry.

D) INCORRECT:

Neurofibromatosis, an autosomal dominant condition, has variable expressivity. The severity of disease and clinical findings vary among individuals within the same family and between different families. Prenatal genetic testing is available for families with one or more members who have been affected by the disease. Neurofibromatosis occurs in all ethnic groups.

E) INCORRECT:

Phenylketonuria is an autosomal recessive disease. Screening for this condition is part of the standard metabolic screen that all newborns in the United States receive. Prenatal screening for phenylketonuria is also available to mothers with a family history of the disorder.
